xccdf:Benchmark.xccdf:title: USGCB: Guidance for Securing Microsoft Windows 7 Firewall
xccdf:Benchmark.xccdf:description: This guide has been created to assist IT professionals, in effectively securing systems with Microsoft Windows 7 Firewall
xccdf:Benchmark.xccdf:notice: Do not attempt to implement any of the settings in this guide without first testing them in a non-operational environment. NIST assumes no responsibility whatsoever for its use by other parties, and makes no guarantees, expressed or implied, about its quality, reliability, or any other characteristic. NIST would appreciate acknowledgement if the document and template are used.
xccdf:Benchmark.xccdf:front-matter: The Federal CIO council created the Technology Information Subcommittee (TIS) at the direction of OMB to govern, among other federal activities, the FDCC iniatitive. The TIS, based on federal agency input, selects platforms and applcations for federal implementation. The TIS also is the Change Control Board (CCB) for configuration settings. As stated in the Federal CIO Council Memo to federal agencies, "The USGCB settings replace the Federal Desktop Core Configuration (FDCC) settings and provide the recommended security baselines for Information Technology products widely deployed across the agencies."
xccdf:Benchmark.xccdf:rear-matter:
Trademark Information
Microsoft, Windows, Windows 7, Windows XP, Windows Vista, Internet Explorer, and Windows Firewall are either registered trademarks or trademarks of Microsoft Corporation in the United States and other countries.
All other names are registered trademarks or trademarks of their respective companies.

xccdf:reference.dc:publisher: National Institute of Standards and Technology

xccdf:metadata.publisher: National Institute of Standards and Technology
xccdf:metadata.dc:creator: National Institute of Standards and Technology
xccdf:metadata.dc:contributor: National Institute of Standards and Technology

xccdf:Profile.xccdf:title: United States Government Configuration Baseline version 1.3.0.1
xccdf:Profile.xccdf:description: This profile represents guidance outlined in Federal Core Configuration settings for Windows 7 Firewall on desktop systems.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Introduction
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: This guide has been created to assist federal agencies in effectively securing systems with Microsoft Windows 7 Firewall based on OMB United States Government Configuration Baseline recommendations. Under the direction of OMB and in collaboration with DHS, DISA, NSA, USAF, and Microsoft, NIST has provided the following baseline to help agencies test, implement, and deploy the Microsoft Windows 7 Firewall United States Government Configuration Baseline (USGCB) baseline. The United States Government Configuration Baseline (USGCB) is an OMB-mandated security configuration. Please refer to the USGCB home page for additional information. http://USGCB.nist.gov

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: USGCB Other Settings
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: USGCB has identified the following additional controls that must be checked in order to verify compliance.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Core Networking - Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP-In)
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: To allow the client to receive DHCP resonses that would otherwise be blocked by CCE-9069-6.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Inbound Rules

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Core Networking - Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCPV6-In)
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: To allow the client to receive DHCPV6 resonses that would otherwise be blocked by CCE-9069-6.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Inbound Rules

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security - Domain Profile
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: The Domain Profile applies when a computer is connected to a network and authenticates to a domain controller in the domain to which the computer belongs.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Log Dropped Packets
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The "Log Dropped Packets" option for the Windows Firewall should be configured correctly for the Domain Profile.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Domain Profile Tab\Logging

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The "Log Successful Connections" option for the Windows Firewall should be configured correctly for the Domain Profile.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The log file path and name for the Windows Firewall should be configured correctly for the Domain Profile.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall with Advanced Security\Windows Firewall Properties\Domain Profile Tab\Logging

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Size Limit
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The log file size limit for the Windows Firewall should be configured correctly for the Domain Profile.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security - Private Profile
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: The Private Profile only applies if a user with local administrator privileges assigns it to a network that was previously set to Public. Microsoft recommends only doing this for a trusted network.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: private_profile_log_dropped_packets_var

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security - Public Profile
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: The Public Profile is the default network location type when the computer is not connected to a domain. Public profile settings should be the most restrictive because the computer is connected to a public network where security cannot be as tightly controlled as within an IT environment.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: public_profile_log_dropped_packets_var
